awd_abstract_narration:
Since 1984, the NSF's highly successful Engineering Research Centers (ERC) Program has led the Foundation in developing innovative new modes of support for research and education, led U.S. academic institutions to evolve the ways in which research is structured and form intellectual and financial partnerships with industry, produced thousands of engineering graduates who are highly productive leaders and innovators in industry and academe, and enabled thousands of innovative new technologies and companies that have stimulated the U.S. economy and provided a substantial return on NSF's investment.  The proposed project is the second phase of a two-part project to prepare a detailed, book-length History of the ERC Program over the program's more than 30-year span. The History will serve the national interest by providing lessons learned, best practices, and management guidance to government program managers, academic faculty and administrators, and industry leaders regarding the structure, operation, and management of such centers, not only in engineering but in any field of science and technology. 

The ERC Program History will be published as an e-book to have the maximum reach to different interested communities. The core narrative of the History will contain hundreds of links to ancillary material in various media - official documents, interview summaries, personal essays, meeting presentations, reports, graphics, videos, and captured websites. This material will be accessible to audiences ranging from engineering faculty and students to academic administrators and government officials, to industry executives and research managers, and to scholars of history and the management of technology. The online History will be marketed via email and the Web to all these audiences nationwide and worldwide. The book-length narrative and its ancillary resources will together provide a thoroughly documented understanding of how various groups involved in the ERC Program responded to the challenges inherent in the ERC construct, and how through their collective experiences it evolved through time to become one of the most recognized, respected, and productive centers programs worldwide.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this project was to produce and publish a detailed history of the National Science Foundation’s Engineering Research Centers (ERC) Program (available at https://erc-history.erc-assoc.org/). The secondary goals were to describe the evolution of ERC Program goals, key features, and management; to explore and document how the Program’s important impacts in research, education, and industrial collaboration were achieved and to educate the History’s various audiences about these achievements; to provide policy and management guidance to a range of interested audiences; and to capture the historical details for posterity, including historians and other scholars.

Intellectual Merit

The History is valuable from a management standpoint for those planning or operating government programs to support academic research centers, for those planning or operating centers, for administrators of center host institutions, and for representatives of industrial firms engaged in ongoing centers or contemplating joining centers because it contains detailed information on processes, outcomes, and lessons learned. The History also contains useful summaries of the state of the art at various points in time in emerging fields impacted by ERCs and enabled by their interdisciplinary configuration.

The History is useful to those planning or operating academic research centers in terms of strategies and lessons learned regarding:  

  • organizing and managing interdisciplinary teams of faculty and students to pursue research with shared goals;
  • staffing of the various functions in a large academic research center and the roles served by staff;
  • engineering and technical workforce development, including improving the diversity of the workforce and of engineering faculty;
  • overhead return and multi-institutional collaborations;
  • post-award oversight, reporting, and data collection; and
  • technology transfer to industry partners and center-associated startups, as well as industrial collaboration/membership in general.

Broader Impacts

The ERC Program History should have a broader impact in terms of lessons learned regarding the management and dynamics of large academic and/or research organizations, regardless of field, and their impact on student education as well as on the culture of academe locally and more broadly. There is also an impact on the education of large numbers of precollege students and teachers, resulting in a more technically literate public (as opposed to technology development as such). In addition, there is a potential impact on those studying, or preparing to form and operate, government/university/industry partnerships within the US or other governments.
